title: 106_hr4091
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Limpopo River Debt Relief and Reconstruction Act of 2000". The Congress finds severe flooding in southern African countries, particularly in Mozambique along the Limpopo River. The extent of death and destruction is unknown, with hundreds of thousands homeless and in need of food, water, medicine, blankets, and tents. Many roads and bridges are also affected. Many countries in southern Africa have experienced severe infrastructure damage due to flooding, requiring long-term economic and technical assistance for reconstruction. Debt cancellation and reconstruction aid are crucial for these countries to address immediate needs, repair infrastructure, and rebuild their economies. TITLE I--DEBT RELIEF

SEC. 101. BILATERAL DEBT FORGIVENESS. The President shall cancel all amounts owed to the United States by eligible countries as a result of loans, guarantees, or credits. Debt cancellation under this provision is not considered assistance and certain prohibitions do not apply. The President has the authority to cancel debt owed by eligible countries, regardless of certain provisions of the law. The authorization of appropriations is provided for the cost of debt cancellation for fiscal years 2001 and 2002. The Congress urges the President to use influence within the Paris Club to cancel debt owed by eligible countries. The Secretary of the Treasury shall instruct US Executive Directors at various financial institutions to urge debt cancellation. Chapter 9 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to authorize assistance for relief and reconstruction in southern Africa due to severe flooding in 2000. Assistance will be provided on a grant basis and in accordance with existing policies. Authorized appropriations for fiscal years 2001 and 2002 to carry out relief and reconstruction assistance in southern Africa. The Congress urges the President to use US influence in the Paris Club to encourage member countries to provide grants for infrastructure repair in flood-affected southern Africa. The Secretary of the Treasury will instruct US Executive Directors at international financial institutions to advocate for grants to repair infrastructure in flood-affected countries in southern Africa. Eligible countries include Botswana, Lesotho, Madagascar, Mozambique, South Africa, Swaziland, Zambia, and Zimbabwe.
